Award.AwardTitle: Effect of Heating/Cooling Cycles on the Thermomechanical Performance of Energy Piles

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Energy piles are deep foundation elements designed to access and exploit the relatively constant temperature of the ground and its heat storage capacity for efficient heating and cooling of buildings. Energy piles present an innovative way to harvest near-surface geothermal energy, while at the same time serve as foundations for buildings and other structures such as bridges. This research project answers two fundamental questions related to the behavior of energy piles under thermally induced load cycles: (1) Do the thermal load cycles change the properties of the soil around the energy pile on an elemental level, thereby affecting the pile's load-deformation behavior? (2) Do the thermal load cycles alter the soil-pile interface properties on an elemental level, thereby reducing the axial load capacity of the pile? The research project focuses both on the effect of cyclic straining and deformations at the pile-soil interface as well as the effect of temperature cycles on soil behavior. This research will quantify the effect of temperature cycles on serviceability (i.e. temperature induced settlement) and ultimate state (i.e. capacity) of energy piles, and will investigate heat exchange behavior and temperature-induced effects around the energy pile through a carefully designed laboratory testing program, a full-scale field test, and advanced numerical modeling. This research will help us better understand energy pile behavior with particular emphasis on the fundamental aspects of soil-pile interface behavior. Findings from this research will help us develop refined design guidelines for energy piles.

Energy piles provide the means to use the ground as a renewable heating and cooling resource, thereby reducing the demand on conventional energy sources, reducing seasonal energy demand fluctuations on the electric power system, and reducing harmful CO2 emissions. A better understanding of the fundamental aspects of energy pile behavior will have broad impact on the use of pile foundations as heat exchangers. The study has the potential to increase the use of energy pile systems on a commercial scale in the U.S. and worldwide. The project will also integrate research and education to support the emerging workforce needed to grow the nation's green energy industry, an area that is growing and in need of educated professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Shallow geothermal energy is commonly used to provide thermal needs for residential and commercial buildings. Shallow geothermal energy is defined as shallow solar energy flux, found within 10-60 m of the ground surface, where temperature usually ranges from 10° C to 25° C. During winter this technology extracts heat from the relatively warm soil (heat source) via a heat pump that disposes the heat in the building for heating purposes.  The opposite occurs during summer where the heat from the warm building is extracted via the same heat pump and disposed in the relatively cold soil (heat sink). As one of the promising renewable energy sources, this technology can be used as an efficient alternative for fossil fuel thus resulting in the reduction of environmental pollution and greenhouse gas emissions.

An energy pile is a pile foundation (for residential and commercial buildings) that uses shallow geothermal energy to heat/cool a building. The pile includes a closed-loop system with a series of polyethylene pipes embedded in a reinforced concrete pile circulating water to transfer heat from ground to the superstructure and vice versa. The energy pile serves as a foundation element for the superstructure and a heat exchanger simultaneously. Like other piles, the interface between the soil and the concrete plays a critical role in determining the frictional capacity along the shaft of energy piles. In energy piles, however, frequent injection/extraction of heating generates alternating expansion/contraction in the concrete, the surrounding soil and the soil-concrete interface. This cyclic thermal behavior may affect the shaft capacity of an energy pile in two ways: (1) it imposes successive cyclic movement along the interface, which may result in interface shear strength/stiffness degradation; and (2) cyclic heating/cooling of the surrounding soil may affect soil strength thus affecting the pile load carrying capacity. These two effects create a complex interface behavior under thermal loading. Understanding this complex behavior is important for proper design of energy piles.

One of the major objectives of this research is to address some of the questions in connection with the thermo-mechanical response of clay-concrete interface under various thermal loading conditions using a direct shear test apparatus that was modified to better reflect the soil-pile interface behavior due to thermal expansion/contraction. The unique design of the modified direct shear test apparatus allows the concrete specimen to expand/contract freely when the interface is subjected to cycles of heating/cooling thus simulating the interface behavior of an energy pile subjected to similar thermal loading conditions.

The effect of thermal loading on shaft resistance of a concrete energy pile embedded in soft Kaolin clay was investigated via a lab scale model. The model energy pile was a subsection of a concrete energy pile allowed to move freely without end bearing. Five pile load tests were performed in undrained conditions after the piles were subjected to various types of thermal loading with temperatures ranging from 24 to 34° C. The testing approach and the results offered a good insight into the changes in shaft resistance due to thermal loading, although there are some limitations related to the effects of scaling and boundary conditions.

The following is a summary of important findings that may have significant effects on energy pile design:

  1. In the lab scale pile tests, heating phase of the first thermal cycle resulted in generation of excess pore pressure in the surrounding soil. In the subsequent cycles, however, pore pressure stayed below zero even during heating periods and relatively large negative pore pressure was developed during cooling periods. As for non-cyclic heating, pore pressure increased in the beginning of heating period and then gradually decreased approaching zero at the end of the heating period.
  2. Significant increase in shaft resistance was caused by thermal loading. The increase was more pronounced when the pile was loaded at a constant temperature of 34° C (w/o cycling).
  3. Effective stress analysis (β method) was employed to explain test results. Thermally-induced improvements of interface friction angle () and effective lateral stress () are responsible for shaft resistance enhancement.
  4. The results showed a clear increase in the initial stiffness of shaft resistance with temperature increase.
